title: Revealed: Hackers tried to blackmail David Beckham for £1m to avoid embarrassing email leak
text:
Revealed: Hackers tried to blackmail David Beckham for £1m to avoid embarrassing email leak David Beckham carrying out charity work in the Philippines Credit: Unicef Rozina Sabur 6 February 2017 • 8:39am 
D avid Beckham refused to pay £1 million to blackmailers to stop a leak of his emails, it has been reported. 
Hackers believed to be using Russian servers accessed millions of messages and documents from the computer system of Simon Oliveira's agency which runs Mr Beckham's publicity. 
The cyber criminals allegedly demanded a sum of one million euros - close to £1 million - not to expose the sensitive emails. 
Leaked emails between Mr Beckham and his publicist Mr Oliveira suggested his attempts to use his charity work were part of a campaign for a knighthood. 
In one message the 41-year-old former England captain branded the Honours Committee "unappreciative c***s" after missing out on a knighthood in 2013 and dismissed lesser awards, ranting: "Unless it's a knighthood f*** off". Kirsty Young and David Beckham who will join Desert Island Discs for their 75th anniversary celebrations Credit: BBC 
I n the emails Mr Beckham also allegedly states: “It’s a disgrace to be honest and if I was American I would have got something like this 10 years ago.” 
But the former footballer, who received an OBE from the Queen in 2003, rejected the claims, maintaining that some of the emails had been doctored and others had been taken out of context. 

A police investigation has been underway in Portugal, where Oliveira's firm has its servers, for the last 12 months. Hackers approached Doyen Sports in Portugal, part of Mr Oliveira's firm Doyen Global, according to the Daily Mirror . 
Mr Beckham's team refused to cooperate with the blackmailers and called the police early last year, the newspaper reported. 
A source said: "They approached by email and attempted to meet via another third party. 
"The investigation has been going on behind the scenes for some time and involved several prominent companies." David Beckham with daughter Harper 
T he blackmailer, going by the fake name Artem Lovuzov, told Doyen Sports chief executive Neilo Lucas: "A generous donation, and you can be sure that all the information I possess will be destroyed." 
When there was no response, the blackmailer wrote: "I'm giving you until 16.00 on Tuesday to contact my lawyer with a view to a proper resolution to this impasse." 
The hackers are understood to have targeted a number of businesses connected to the football world. 
It emerged as Katherine Jenkins hit back at Beckham over his criticism of her in the leaked emails. 
Ms Jenkins reeled off a list of her charity achievements in response. Professor Jonathan Shalit, her manager, told the Sun: "Katherine was awarded an OBE for her services to music and charity. 
"She has performed for Presidents and Royalty including at Westminster Cathedral in honour of Pope John Paul II's Silver Jubilee and Her Majesty the Queen's 00th birthday celebrations." 
Mr Beckham broke his social media silence over the weekend to pay tribute to Man United's Busby Babes who were killed in the 1958 Munich air crash. A photo posted by David Beckham (@davidbeckham) on Feb 5, 2017 at 12:59am PST 
H is son Brooklyn, 17, also posted an image of his father with his five-year-old sister Harper. A photo posted by David Beckham (@davidbeckham) on Feb 5, 2017 at 12:59am PST 
W ife Victoria is understood to have flown from London to the US over the weekend to be at New York Fashion week. Victoria Beckham and husband David Beckham Credit: EPA 
U nicef, the charity which Mr Beckham has worked closely with, also came to the star’s defence. 
Although it would not comment on the veracity of the emails because it had not seen the originals, it described Beckham “as generously giving his time, energy and support to help raise awareness and funds for Unicef's work for children”. Follow Telegraph News
